contentrichtext.text: {|align=right |- |{{Infobox Tolkien character | character_name = Déagol | character_alias = Nahald | character_race = [[Hobbit]] | Book(s) = ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'' (1954)| }} |} '''Déagol''' is a fictional character in [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s [[Tolkien's legendarium|legendarium]]. His story is related in ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'', the first of three volumes comprising Tolkien's most famous novel, ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', in the chapter "The Shadow of the Past". ==Biography== Déagol was a [[Stoor]] [[Hobbit]]<ref>{{ME-ref|UT|Part Three, IV. "The Hunt for the Ring", p 353, note 9}}. In a letter quoted by Christopher Tolkien, Tolkien refers to Déagol and Sméagol as Stoors.</ref> who lived in a small community bound by kinship ties—akin to a [[clan]]. He had a relative<ref>{{ME-ref|fotr|"The Shadow of the Past"}} They are popularly thought to be cousins, but Tolkien only calls them "friends" in ''The Lord of the Rings''. In a later letter (''The Letters of J. R. R. Tolkien'', #214) he writes that they were "evidently relatives".</ref> named [[Gollum|Sméagol]], whose grandmother was the [[matriarch]] of the community. In 2463 of the [[Third Age]], Déagol became the third [[One Ring#Ring-bearers|bearer]] of the [[One Ring]], after [[Sauron]] and [[Isildur]]. He found the Ring—which had been lost for thousands of years—while fishing with Sméagol in the [[Gladden (Middle-earth)|Gladden]] river. Instantly ensnared by its beauty and seductive power, Sméagol demanded the Ring as his "birthday-present". When Déagol refused to give it up, Sméagol strangled him and hid his body, which was never found; nevertheless, the murderer (nicknamed ''[[Gollum]]'' after the swallowing noises he made) was eventually driven from his home and into the [[Misty Mountains]]. ==Name== {{further2|[[Gollum#Name|Gollum]]}} The name "Déagol" is from [[Old English]] ''dēagol'' (more commonly spelt ''dīegol''), meaning "secretive".<ref name="ntc">{{cite book|title=The New Tolkien Companion|year=1977|last=Tyler|first=J.E.A.|isbn=0380469049}}</ref> In Tolkien's ''[[Red Book of Westmarch]]'', the name "Déagol" is used as a translation of the "original" name in the author-invented language of [[Westron]], "'''Nahald'''",<ref name="ntc" /> which has the same meaning. ==Adaptations== Déagol appears in the prologue to [[Ralph Bakshi]]'s 1978 animated adaptation of ''[[The Lord of the Rings (1978 film)|''The Lord of the Rings]]''. In [[Peter Jackson]]'s 2001–2003 [[The Lord of the Rings film trilogy|live-action adaptations]] of ''The Lord of the Rings'', Déagol is played by New Zealand actor [[Thomas Robins]]. His scenes with [[Andy Serkis]] (Sméagol/Gollum) were originally planned to be in ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers]]'', but were moved to ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]''. ==See also== {{Portal|Middle-earth}} *[[Gladden Fields]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=0992718|name=Thomas Robins}} {{TolkienGateway|Déagol}} {{Lotr}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Deagol}} [[Category:Bearers of the One Ring]] [[Category:Characters in The Lord of the Rings]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1954]] [[Category:Fictional fishers]] [[Category:Middle-earth Hobbits]] [[fr:Liste de Hobbits de la Terre du Milieu#Autres]] [[pl:Lista hobbitów Śródziemia#Déagol]] [[fi:Luettelo Keski-Maan sivuhahmoista#Muut]]
